reviewText:
Early Access Review

(This review only applies for Unturned 2.0)

One of few apocalypse survival games that truly grows from the community. The dev works on this everyday and is always looking for feedback and opinions on how the game is shaped, also constantly putting out strawpolls to the community and listens to us.

Unturned is played how you want, example, if you only want PVE you can select your server and if you want a PVP experience with your PVE you can select PVP enabled on your server, and yes, you can host your own servers on your computer.

It starts out like many other apocalypse survival games: you start out with your fists and 4 slots for your inventory. You have a lot of places you can wander to when you spawn, like a cabin camp, small town, military base, and many more. Your main mission when you start is to grab a melee, some food with drink, and a backpack. Once you've acquired these necessities, you may wish to find a gun if you want to PVP, or you may want to collect seeds to start a farm, or even start chopping down trees to make yourself a cozy place to spend the night.

The PVP system is great also, server hosts can select if players can bring in loot from their server (best for PVP) or not be able to bring loot in (Best for PVE Immersion). Their is a leaning system so you can peek corners also. You can also SHOOT OUT OF CARS (but not from the drivers seat of course)! Load some of your buddies in the trunk of your truck and do a hillbilly drive-by if you wish!

The towns are well structured for PVP also, their are lot of CQC battles to be fought, and also small hills for sniping, but snipers can be easily flanked if you don't post up right!

Base raiding is also important in PVP too. People on public servers will build structured bases equipped with sniper pits, plenty of windows, and escape routes! You must observe a player's base and attack it strategically, you never know how many players may be in there!

Now, time to farm my crops and build my base, I recommend you do so also!

Steam group link for clan: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/TheMicBrothers

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Best survival I've played in a while

The game is full of places to explore, hunt, and scavenge for items to survive. With a variety of weapons and attachments at your disposal, you can hunt down animals, zombies, and other players.

(Weapon Segment)

The fact that every attachment is compatable with every weapon, as long as it has the slot for it (Barrel, Tactical, Sight, ect.), Makes choosing your weapon fun. You have yourself an Outfield? Put a Silencer, Bipod, and a x12 Scope on it and you have an effective silenced sniper. Don't have a x12 Scope, Silencer, or Bipod? Take 2 duct tape and craft it with binoculars. Then take 2 empty cans and 2 cans of Cola and craft them with fire from a Campfire. Finally, find a Tactical Laser. All these will make a Zoomomatic (Scope that is better than the x6, but no reticle), a Muffler (Silent shooting, but muzzle flash still active), and the Tactical laser acts as a reticle for the Zoomomatic. It's the small things like this that I love in survival games. Being able to create a makeshift sniper using little Millitary grade equipment is just one example of the combinations of weapons and attachments.

(Survival Segment)

The surviving aspect is also amazing. Hunger, Thirst, and Illness are what keep you alive. Unlike most games, they go up as you get hungry, thirsty, and sick (At least in the games I've played, they go down). Make sure to Keep them down by eating food and drinking any drink. Illness can be gained from multiple sources, such as getting hit by zombies and eating raw/rotten foods and drinks. Illness can only be brought down with Vitamins, Anti-biotics, and a type of berry and it's crushed counterpart. You can go from town to town scavenging food and drinks, or you can take to the hills in search of wildlife to hunt. Grab a fire axe, handsaw, and pickaxe to start building a base in the hills, or fortify the roof of a building. Build traps for zombies and players alike. Light up an area with generators and worklights.

(Experience Segment)

As you hunt animals, kill zombies, collect wood, and mine rocks, you will tend to notice a notification at the top of your screen informing you that you have gained som experience. At the start of Unturned, you are very vulnurable, But fear not. Pressing the button you have bound to open up inventory (Default is Tab) will reveal....your inventory. At the bottom you will see three tabs labeled Apperal, Crafting, and Skills. Selecting Skills will replace your character at the right with many options. The top shows your current experience and the red bars show the ammount of levels it can be upgraded by (Red being levels not yet achieved and Green being current level). For starters, you should focus on upgrading Survival (Slower thirst and hunger gained) and Immunity (Heal more effectivly and less Illness gained from zombie hits and raw/rotten foods). After that, you can decide if you want to upgrade Stamina to outrun the zombies or Warrior to fight back. Build more structures and traps with Crafting. Sneak around zombies and towards wildlife with Sneakybeaky. Take the shot with little recoil thanks to Marksman. Chop and mine faster with Outdoors. These Skills make surviving easier, just make sure to keep an eye on the Hunger and Thirst bar.

In summary, this game as a fantastic weapon system, challenging survival, and rewarding skills. 10/10 for both the game and this being my longest review ever.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, this is Unturned. What is Unturned, you may be asking? Well, it's an indie zombie survival game, packed with plenty of features. Let me run through them.

Looting, Inventory, and Crafting
So, Unturned has a fairly in-depth looting and inventory system.

- Items have physics, so if you, for example, drop a log down a hill, it will roll down. Apart from that, there are various locations where you can gather loot, such as grocery stores, pharmacies, barracks, on ships, in containers, and more.

-  The inventory system is very in depth, each piece of clothing you equip will give you more inventory slots to carry more items. There is also different pieces of armour that protect from damage inflicted by bullets.

-  As for the crafting, when you get different items, you can combine them to create makeshift weapons, vaccines, barricades, and even vehicles.

Maps and serverlist
- In Unturned, there are 3 different official maps: PEI, Washington, and Yukon. Washington is a purely PVP map, Yukon is a purely Survival map, and PEI is somewhere inbetween.

- The Serverlist is a huge improvement, instead of connecting via IP, now there is a list which you can browse and filter out difficulty, security (VAC-secured/Non-VAC-secured), first/thirdperson, and Workshop, which brings me onto my next point.


Workshop mods and map editor
- Yup, Unturned has Workshop Mods, which allows people to upload new vehicles, maps, and weapons, for others to download and try out.

- Map Editor: Yes, this is also a thing. It's used to create maps to upload to the workshop, and you can place objects, transform terrain, put player and item spawns, etc. Pretty useful, but baking materials requires a pretty beefy PC (or otherwise a couple-minute-wait)


Weapons and Vehicles.
In Unturned, there are a variety of weapons and vehicles.

- There are 4 Assault Rifles, 4 Carbines, 3 Shotguns, 2 LMGs, 6 pistols, 1 Railgun, 1 Rocket Launcher, 1 Nailgun, 5 bows, 3 sniper rifles, 2 sharpshooter rifles, and 6 civilian rifles.

- As for vehicles, there are golf carts, vans, sedans, hatchbacks, trucks, roadsters, quad bikes, snow mobiles, tractors, taxis, buses, snow explorers, ambulances, police cars, fire trucks, Urals (tan and forest), APCs (amphibious, tan and forest), Humvees (tan and forest), Jeeps (tan and forest), racecars, and 3 different types of makeshift vehicles (1 seater, 4 seater, 6 seater)

- There are also two planes (one sea-plane, one normal), four helicopters (Skycrane type helicopter, a Police helicopter, a Hummingbird, and a Huey in tan and forest.), and three boats (jetskis, a speedboat, and police boat.)


Weapon skins and cosmetics
So there are also weapon skins and cosmetics, cosmetics being applied to your character and changing the look, and weapon skins change the look of your gun, ranging from camo skins to glowing, luminescent skins that sell for dozens of dollars.


Buildables
In Unturned, you can build entire bases, or just barricade up a pre-existing house. Freeform buildables allow you to angle walls, barricades, traps, etc, and also allow you to attach them to cars, turning that crappy old Sedan into a tank using metal sheets and barbed wire, or putting crates in a helicopter to transport gear around.




Conclusion
That just about wraps up my Unturned review. Thanks for reading this far.








There's drinkable maple syrup. 10/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Easily one of the best free to play games on Steam. This is a genre that has been over-done, but Unturned manages to be unique in it's own way. Kill zombies, gather resources, hunt animals, craft things and scavenge for items. That's all you do.

You only have 3 types of enemies in Unturned, there's the normal, the military and the Mega zombies, the latter being quite rare and way more powerful which will make you want to run if you encounter one, especially if you're playing on Hard, but Unturned is more about the quantity of enemies... if you get swarmed, you're gonna have a bad time!

The beauty in Unturned stands in how simple it is, yet manages to be fun and quite graphically stunning. The developer team is just one single developer, and he's about 17 years old, that is something that should always be remembered, because not only does he update the game on a regular basis (about twice a week now), he has improved this game from an almost unplayable mess for older computers which was v2.0, to a polished and really smooth game v3.0 is.

I still haven't bought the Gold Upgrade, but I'm planning on doing it, just because I want to donate" to Nelson Saxton

Real Review:

This game is really fun and it's freaking FREE. What more could you ask? This game was created by Nelson Sexton who was 16 at the time. Talented. The improvements that have been made to this game have been substantial within the past years. I think whenever I try to describe it to my friends, I compare it to like a Minecraft with guns, without as much crafting. It's a survival, apocolyptic style game. You can either go single player and test yourself alone, or you can join servers where you can either team up, gain trusts of other groups and join them, create a survival team, or get killed on sight by Bandits or be a bandit. You will roam town to town searching for food and drinks that hopefully are edible and nonspoiled. Zombies will be infested in every town. So look carefully for that assault rifle or military knife to fend yourself against them. HAHA if only! Until then, you will have a higher chance of using rakes, butcher knives and baseball bats. Still not happy with it? Find some nails, rope and glue and make a makeshift bat that has nails in it. Find axes in the fire station or find some luck in the police headquarters and get yourself a Colt .45 and a bulletproof vest. You're gonna want to make a move, so find a gas tank and a car or walk. Don't feel like doing either? Cut down some trees with your axe and start crafting. Feeling lonely? This game supports singleplayer and multiplayer. You can join vanilla servers on the regular PEI map or you can join servers that have mods with commands and airdrops, where weapons spawn in different towns every 10 minutes and people fight for the loot almost like the Hunger Games.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSince there's hardly any actual reviews regarding this game with factual information, I've decided to write one. This game is a free-to-play steam game, so obviously anyone can really play this. That being said, unturned is a zombie survival game which requires you to gather weapons, food, water, and other resources to stay alive. So far there are 3 (official) maps implimented into the game. It's possible to download more along with other weapons and items from the community workshop. You can play this game by yourself, with friends, or just join a multiplayer server. The game offers PVP and PVE game types. The game offers 3 difficulty types: easy, normal, and hard. If you do play this game and decide you like it, you can always purchase the Permanent Gold Upgrade" for $4.99 which gives you a few gold items for your character. The money goes to Nelson Sexton
date: the creator of Unturned. Anyway with that review being said
recommended:
let's list the pro's and con's!

Pro's:
-Free-to-play (unless you decide to support Nelson buy purchasing the gold upgrade)
-Fun to play for any age group
-Ability to play on a private server with friends (using hamachi)
-Crafting system
-Level up/skills system
-Free form building and the ability to create your own base
-Many different weapons and items
-Huge maps that offer a lot of stuff to do

Con's:
-The community on servers is cancer. They're basically a 10 year old version of DayZ or H1Z1 players.
-The hit range can sometimes be a bother. Seems like zombies can hit you a lot farther away than you can hit them.
-The night cycle seems rather long.

Anyway that's my review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The term 'Free-to-Play' is slapped onto the side of a lot of games nowadays and it rarely lives up to expectations, with many of them carrying the undertone of 'Pay-to-Win'. With Unturned this isn't the case.

The game is a completely free to play zombie survival game, there is an option to pay to upgrade this to a Gold membership however this is purely for aesthetic purposes - Newer/slick UI, extra character model customisations, Gold username displays on the in-game chat, you can also gain access to gold-member-only servers with a few % bonuses like exp and loot but this is a level playing field as you can only play with other Gold members with these bonuses.

I don't wish to give much away about the gameplay but the game is awesome to play with friends and you can set up your own private servers fairly easily.

There are a few bits and pieces that I feel could and most-likely will be improved in the near future:
(There is currently a huge overhaul in development to the game so these points may/may not be valid once the update is live)

The crafting system has pretty much zero guidance, and the recipes aren't exactly obvious. I don't like being spoon-fed but Stick + Bolts = Torch didn't occur naturally to me. The wiki contains everything you need to know about crafting.
(Only in Player vs Environment) Once you have fortified, armed/equipped yourself, and have a steady income of growing crops the game becomes a lot less challenging - although I still manage to die in the simplest of situations... I would love to see roaming hordes on this game.
At present the game only has one map, although the developer (The one developer working on this title) is in the process of creating a new Canada map.
Hackers are a bit of a nuisance in online PvP servers.
The above notes are just from my own personal take and experience of the game so far.

These aside, I love the simple, blocky graphics, the open world feel, the insatiable appetite of your character - same goes for the zombies, the weapons and attachments, the survival mechanics, the trust issues, the uneasy silences, the countless naked respawns etc etc.

I would really recommend this game to anyone who enjoys surviving with friends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As you play, you will have to worry about four main things; Irradiation, hunger, thirst, and health. Irradiation is the hardest to take care of once you progress. If you get into battles with hoardes of zombies, you can easily die due to radiation sickness.

Health is also pretty dificult to take care of, but not nearly as much. You can heal from eating, using medkits, and a few other actions. Hunger and thirst are the easiest to take care of. You can find canteens, and fill them with ocean water to avoid having to find bottled water or soda. You can also grow crops, and cultivate a farm at a location of your choice.  A few tips I can give are:

Set up a base away from zombies or towns, they can attack and destroy crops, and bases.

Be sure to NEVER provoke zombies once you first start with no weapon, unless you are an older player.

Also, make sure that the first thing you do is raid a farmhouse, you can find arrows, bows, guns, axes, bats, chainsaws, etc.

You will sometimes find what I like to call the Hulk"
It is a zombie that is larger than normal

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't let the graphics mislead you. This is actually a well packed Zombie survival game. It's frequently updated by one of the most responsive dev i've seen in Early Access.
It's Free to play but no 'pay to win.' It has workshop, marketplace and even a map editor for you to build your own zombie apocalypse.

I know it's free. But go buy the gold upgrade, it's worth supporting Nelson so he keeps updating this nice game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is an example of an F2P game done right. You have access to EVERYTHING, except for extra customization for your character. And, to get the extra customization? Get the gold upgrade. And it's permanent, unlike other F2P games where you have to make $50 microtransactions every month for an account. It's very realistic, and with great mechanics and items and realism. Also, thought I'd mention this game is made by a 17-year-old guy. No-one else. One of the best games I've played. 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unturned is where DayZ meets Minecraft.  It's developed by a 17 year old Canadian who is connected to the community and committed to updating/patching regularly.  The game, while still in development, has a lot going for it.  There's a lot of items, a good crafting system, skills to boost, and a survival system.

My complaints so far are the zombies are too slow and easy to kill and the map itself is rather small.  I would also like to see some custom server options to address these issues.  Also this game doesn't seem like it would be much fun single player.  The human element really adds to survival games like this.

I do like what I see and so I bought the DLC to throw some money to the dev for his fun, free game.  I consider it an investment for further growth.

So do I recommend it?  Yes.  Grabs some friends and try it out.  It's free so you have nothing to lose.  Then keep your eye on the development and we will see where this goes.  Who knows maybe I'll see you out there.  You'll know it's me when you see a guy wearing nothing but a chef's hat, and is tripping out of his mind, and clenching a sledgehammer menacingly.  You know what?  You might want to go the other direction.  He's weird.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unturned is a very easy game to judge at first glance. It doesn't appear to have amazing graphics, it has a Roblox-looking vibe, and there are noobs everywhere. Well, some of this IS true, but this is one of those games that you have to submerge yourself in a little before the true beauty shows. It can be seen as a game where you wander around chugging glue and getting high in order to stay alive a little longer...or it can be seen as a challenging survival experience where strategy is key. With full release said to be coming soon, let's see what early access is like in Unturned.

Unturned is a zombie apocalypse game where you must wander around as a human survivor to collect food, water, keep warm, and avoid zombies to stay alive as long as possible. You can find a plane if you want and go on a joy ride, then maybe you can start building a giant base, storing your prized finds from your adventures. After a few weeks of playing singleplayer, you've done everything. So why not check out multiplayer? There's plenty more to see and experience in this game.

Let's talk about the look, since that's one of the main things we focus on.  The graphics have no crazy detail whatsoever, but that's not the point. The graphics are focused: You see what you need to see. You'll soon find that the models actually look quite pleasing in their basic and rounded look.

Alright what about the survival experience? It can be very challenging in its own unique way.  You need to keep finding fresh food and water to stay alive, and you'll have to strategize and plan where you will go to satisfy your stomach. There is a temperature mechanic, where you will have to take cover in shelter during the cold and dress up to stay warm. It can be difficult to create a sustainable food source outside of towns. In short, the survival aspects in this game always keep you moving around the map like a nomad. You can settle down in one place...but not long before you have to make another run to Big J's Diner for some grub.

Let's talk PvP...a big aspect to this game. If you thought shooting zombies with a high caliber DragonFang is fun, try shooting at some other players in multiplayer. The gun mechanics are satisfying: You have your standard recoil, your aiming, but where this system really shines is the customization. This ranges from increasing accuracy with a barrel attachment, or alleviating recoil with a nice grip. The melee is pretty great too. With left-click, you get the standard attack for that given weapon. With right-click, and the sacrifice of a little enegery and a longer attack time, you can strike a heavy, hammering attack on both zombies, and players. The aspects put together are very easy to understand, and creates several opportunities for players to have their own technique.

Here are my PROS and CONS.

PROS:

-Great in it's simplicity | It's a very simple looking game, and that makes it special.
-Amazing PvP mechanics | The PvP in this game is very nice and customizable. Well balanced.
-No pay-to-win! | You can buy a Gold upgrade, and gun skins, but never any advantage-granting things.
-Player and UI (User Interface) customizability | Tune your looks to fit your style.
-Ties in with Steam groups | Make a Steam group for your Unturned team, it ties into multiplayer.
-Absolutely free (as of now) | Unturned is 100% free to play (this may change at full release...)!
-Easy to use map maker | The game features a great way for players to make their own maps.
-Steam Workshop capabilities | Design mods, skins, and more with the Steam Workshop!

CONS:

-Limited singleplayer goals | There's not too many goals to keep players on singleplayer.
-A somewhat ugly home sceen | The main screen on start-up is very cluttered with text.


I thought, since this review unexpectedly gained popularity, that I would take advantage of this situation to direct Nelson's attention to some things the community, and I, would like to see before full release. These have been gathered from both me, and comments I've seen from the comminity (Feel free to suggest more things in a reply to this review, I will add them if they seem fit for the game.)

-The return of the original Canada map, restored and re-balanced of course. :)
-Add some more goals to singleplayer, it gets old after everything is acomplished.
-More planes. Some variety might be nice, maybe some dedicated for war, and one for transport.
-Add another map. The official maps that we have as of now, feel rather limited, more would be lovely!
-Add an electrical system to the game. This could include ways to generate electricity, store it (to a certain extent), power other electric-requiring things (this could include car batteries).
-A way to see your Steam friends' name tags and location on the map, and in the world. This will work like the groups system, and can be disabled when the player is set up as anonymous.

Thank you so much for your efforts and time, Nelson!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unturned is another post-apocalyptic survival type game...
What sets it apart from the handful of other survival games coming out lately (After the success of things like minecraft and DayZ) is the heart, the community, the developer, and the fact that it's free haha.
I wouldn't say this game is amazing or inventive, but it is really really fun! The graphics are pretty basic, smooth flat coloured surfaces and blocky character models... but I like them a lot. I think the graphics, more than simple, are just plain charming. I love the silly character customization too. And who doesn't want to be able to survive in the apocalypse with their friends? Multiplayer for games like these is necessary, and I'm glad Unturned supports multiplayer gameplay.

I've heard a lot of people complaining that the beginning is too hard, but honestly as soon as I found a melee weapon I felt pretty set. If anything, I think the gameplay is too easy as it is right now. (This is before the big 3.0 update that is currently in developement) Once I established a base to store things in my character just stopped dying haha. Crafting is confusing and unintuitive though and I felt like it really took too many resources. (But maybe that's just me) the update is fixing that though with a built in crafting menu that gives you recipes based on the resources you have in your inventory. (As far as I can tell)
Once the newest version is released it will have a custom map maker as well! It's fairly easy to use once you've tinkered with it a little bit. I've already seen some amazing content from the community!

Anyway, If you're looking for something different from minecraft and dayz, look elsewhere.
But if you want a fun and simple survival game with lots of respawning zombies to headshot and constant content and gameplay updates, try it out. Why not? It's free! It also has some great PvP potential! (Hiding in fields, wearing camoflauge to sneak up on people, using things like trees, bushes, buildings to stealth with, etc)
Also, the game is being overhauled and so far the beta of the newest version really is adding a lot of improvements! I can't wait to see where this game goes!

Before I finish I'm going to say that the developer (Nelson Sexton) really puts a lot of hard work into this game. He listens to the community well and updates more than the other early access games I'm keeping my eyes on. I really apreciate how much time and effort he manages to put into Unturned.

I recommend buying gold if you like this game! The bonuses are worth the $5. (In my humble opinion)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

THIS IS NOT A NEGATIVE REVIEW, RATHER A WARNING.
Finally, a review that isn't 10/10 would ____ again. Children flock to block-based games and anything that cheap, unfunny, and fake youtubers say a damn thing about. I am tired of it. On the other hand, I am happy to say that I am actively reading comments and making any neccessary changes to the review. Please check back every so often!

And don't even mention the ♥♥♥♥ing crate unboxing garbage.

Unturned:This is a brilliant game that was born on a browser game made for children called ROBLOX. Some of the games on there were actually fun, such as the prototype of this game, and that is why I played it. That prototype eventually became this game that kept getting better. It is now in the 3rd stage of it's early access (Also called 3.0), and it is doing extremely well with a fully fledged workshop and excellent map editor.

Problem: This game, however, has the same problem ROBLOX did on all competitive modes: The damned community. You will constantly be shot or punched by random childish fresh spawns because they have nothing to lose. It's apparently funny for a few minutes? And fully geared people, mature or not, shoot on sight to avoid losing their hard work to people like this. Eventually it becomes a massive clusterf*ck; you have idiots with no gear or a gun with 20 bullets running around just to kill, and then fully geared people going on a sniping spree, some of which are forced to. Seemingly the childish community came here because they like Minecraft or watch PewDiePie. PewDiePie, like any other sh*tty spoiled youtuber, acts like a tard to make a profit and attracts so many children that flood any game that he reviews. Then comes the minecraft part. Is everything that has blocks or pixel graphics automatically minecraft? No. Why does any game that have those attract minecraft audiences? Because the children can't tell the difference. I mean, come on, this game doesn't even abide by a grid. Nelson seems to like it because it makes his game popular and everyone worships him. Children will bow down to a snail. I would rather have noone playing my game at all than to have this.

Solution: The only solution it seems is to play with your friends on a private server. Playing with your friends is fun. Those custom servers that ban KOS are great, too, but the problem with those is that they can often be very strict and/or ran by children, so you might get banned from them with little warning. There are also usually white-list requirements to get on, which nobody likes to go through. And another caution: No KOS/Roleplay servers also tend to allow 'hold ups.' If you ever played Arma, you know what Life RPG is. Basically, it's that with zombies and no police. Like the 'police' ever did anything anyway... Additionally, I for one do not want to have a connection where your IP address is right there for someone to mess with, so Hamachi is rarely a good idea unless you're playing with real-life friends.

Problem 2Another issue is simply the fact that if you are not connected to a server that has a latency of under 100, melee is terrible. The zombies are horribly coded and you simply cannot do anything to defend yourself unless you have infinite ammo for a gun. Their hitboxes are far from where they appear to be when you get the signal of where the zombie is in the game. Another game-breaking issue is how rediculously hard it is to find any useful loot. This is how the loot works: 95% of the time, nothing will spawn. 80% of the time, it will have a durability below 50%. Literally all useable items in the game have a durability. Durability is used up VERY fast. Stamina is used up VERY fast if you don't have the skill maxed. Fuel is used up VERY fast. Hunger/thirst is used up VERY fast. Everything in the game is too fast paced except for the loot, which is too hard to find.

One way to pull it off could be creating a mod that displays a solid contrast color icon above any player not on the PvP list. Shooting them could either get you autokicked or ricochet off of them, not hurting them. Getting on the PvP list requires you to be away from other players and to wait 20 seconds. Getting out requires the 20 second wait and a 2 minute delay between enabling and disabling pvp.

For the second problem, until someone finds a way to slow the zombies down, there's not much that can be done. We also should try and find a way to raise loot spawning. Making durability/fuel/among others slower to be used up would be great as well.

P.S. Please do not comment on my profile or try to friend me, as I will not be playing unturned anytime soon. Instead, please post here. I get a notification with every single comment, so if you want to talk to me, I will always respond if it looks like I should.

P.P.S. Lots of people have been coming here to start a battle against me, be it defending Sir PewDiePie the Loud from heretical invasions or just plain trolls. A lot of them have deleted their comments, and there might be unneccesary clutter from me talking to them. Please dismiss this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Step 1: Get on a server with a couple of your friends.
Step 2: Build a small house on the map.
Step 3: When someone shows up at your house you kill him.
Step 4: Many more waves of people in groups of two show up at your house and you kill them.
Step 5: Someone shows up at your house with grenades.
Step 6: They blow up you and your house.
Step 7: Your friend later finds out is was a misunderstanding with the biggest faction on the server.
Step 8: You think to yourself that that kinda means you’re the strongest faction on the server.
Step 9: You ally the biggest faction on the server and move your base to a new location on the map.
Step 10: One of your friends joins them as an inside man, they don’t know that.
Step 11: The biggest faction on the server moves their base right next to yours.
Step 12: Admins spawn in a ton of logs for the biggest faction on the server so their base can be huge.
Step 13: You and your friends decide to move your base after their was a server wipe.
Step 14: You build your foundation a log off for the day.
Step 15: You log on to realize that the biggest faction on the server has moved their base next to yours again.
Step 16: You and your friend decide you have had enough of them and want to destroy them.
Step 17: As the biggest faction on the server goes off on a loot run your friend chainsaws their base down as you’re a lookout.
Step 18: You set up in a town.
Step 19: The biggest faction on the server sends all their troops to kill you.
Step 20: While you’re away your friend kills of all of them including their leader.
Step 21: Their leader rage quits.
Step 22: You and your friend destroy their new base.
Step 23: You decide that’s enough PvP and you go to play single player.
10/10 Would play again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: This review is from a mostly single player perspective. A few cons won't really apply if you are playing online. I will update it if I ever decide to try out the multiplayer aspects more.

The first thing I tell people when I mention this game is not to judge a book by its cover. Despite its simplistic and blocky appearance, Unturned is a very in-depth survival game and can be loads of fun. If you like survival or crafting games or just killing zombies I'd recommend giving it at try.

It couldn't hurt either way, the game is free to play with an optional gold upgrade" that unlocks some things like special skins
hoursPlayed: and other fluff. It also grants access to "Gold" servers which grant more experience and loot if that is your thing. It's only $5 and I bought it mostly just to support the lone developer. Any money you spend on the game will not give you an advantage nor will anyone else be at an advantage for spending money. You know
voteText:
the way it really should be. Even with access to gold servers everyone is still on a level playing field.

Pros: Several skills to choose from and level up by spending earned experience points as well as a bonus skill that give you unique properties.
Crafting items is simple with plenty of recipes for various items from makeshift weapons to grilled cheese sandwiches. Some require investment in corresponding skills in order to be created.
You can build up bases from wood
helpfulPercent: metal
votesHelpful: or brick as of the time of this review. You can also place most object onto vehicles or create makeshift vehicles. Need mobile storage? Slap a crate or locker down on your vehicle.\nSpeaking of vehicles
votesTotal: there's a good variety. Trucks
votesFunny: vans
commentsCount: sport cars
column16: sedans
column17: and other generic models can be found. Watercraft and aircraft were both recently added as well.\nLots of ways to play. Do you want to scavenge for what you need? How about farm your own crops or hunt wild animals for their meat and hides? Maybe you just want to kick back and fish? Or maybe you just want to hop in a car and mow down some zombies.\nA wide assortment of weapons
column18:
both melee and ranged. Guns and most ranged weapons can be customized with attachments.
Different difficulties and settings to customize your experience if you like.
A built-in map editor if you're creative type.
Workshop support so you can download player made maps and mods.
Relatively bug free in my experiences. I can't think of any time I have encountered one.
Free to play
column19: as I mentioned before. Nothing even remotely "pay to win" about it.\nThe developer is constantly churning out new updates with tweaks
column21:
and additional content.
Just by playing you will occasionally be rewarded with new skins for clothing and weapons. You can buy more or sell the ones you have or just trade them. At any time you can switch between your equipped skins and your actual items' appearances.Cons: Starting out can be more than a little rough sometimes. You might find yourself constantly dying before you can really get on your feet and it usually comes down to luck.
In singleplayer it is a little to easy to get your hands on military weapons and ammo. On servers not so much as there are usually other players already around the spawns to compete with.
Zombies pose very little threat once you reach a certain point.
Zombies cannot leave specified areas. For example if you are in a city and you leave the zombies will only chase you so far before just stopping at the edge of their boundaries. If I remember correctly this was done to increase overall game performance but I could be remembering wrong. Either way it makes areas outside of where zombies spawn completely empty outside of the occasional wildlife. On singleplayer there is little threat outside of cities but in multiplayer there is still always the looming threat of other players.
Guns are purely "point and shoot" with no bullet drop or physics if that matters to you. I personally do not mind as much.Overall it's a good game that keeps getting better. Singleplayer is a good bit of fun but it's more fun to play with friends in my experience. Best of all it's totally free unless you want to drop a little money for some completely optional stuff."

Don't let the graphics fool you, this is a very well made zombie survival game that is still in development. The game offers a nice leveling system that allows you to develop your character in whatever way you want eventually mastering everything.

Keep in mind the game is still in early access and might not  contain hundreds of hours of content to enjoy but its an amazing game to play with friends or even alone  (friends make everything better).

There are hundreds of items in the game, but I'm sure the only thing you want to know is.. Can you build a base/house? a garage maybe? traps? gather resources? YES this is a Zombie Survival game that requires you to maintain your character alive by eating and drinking and killing off zombies.

Again don't let the graphics fool you this game is epic."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first came across this game, I honestly did not expect anything from it because of obvious reasons like the size. But guess what? It's the only game I'm hooked to these days. Survival has never been so luxurious. I know that this game has borrowed a lot of ideas from the other games, none of which I played, but I'm sure this will have new ideas and features as updates follow. And this game is free, so it definitely has a better grip than the rest. There is an update almost everyday as the game is being constantly improved. So I'm confident of a great final product.

Right now, I do have some issues with the frames (FPS). It usually hovers around 20-25, but when I'm building or farming, it's horrible and goes below 10 at times. Not sure if it has got to do with the configuration of my system or if there's a genuine problem behind it. I'm guessing it's my pathetic system.

Playing with friends has never been so fun. Since it's free and small and great, my small-budget friends can also fit in. I can't sleep at times just because I'm constantly thinking of what's required for that perfect" base. It was different in the start
date: though. I found it tough to survive with zombies around in the first few hours. Now I find it tough to survive without them being around. Nothing beats the feeling when I smash their infested heads with my Sledgehammer feeling like Thor.\n\nAnd after all this
recommended: I learn that the guy behind the game is a 17 year old. I'm 17 and I'm nowhere in life. Kudos to him
hoursPlayed: he's definetely pulled off something great. Give him the 5$. He actually deserves much more than that."

Unturned is like a poor man's DayZ. It's a zombie survival game in which you need to survive and collect resources. It has both singleplayer and multiplayer and blocky graphics.

I highly recommend this game becouse of the high level of detail in this game... and it's completely free! 4.5/5

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unturned:
Yup, it's another zombie-survival game, but just because it's traits aren't different, doesn't mean it's a bad game. The graphics are strange, but they're better than many other free games and even some paid ones. Solo is fun, but it does get boring pretty fast sadly. In multiplayer you have 2 choices---> 1: Join a random PvP server or PvE server and meet-up with 99% jerks---> 2: Join a friend's server or create your own, where you can play with or against your friends.
I personally have done both. What I have found (some is based on opinion) are that random servers tend to be more laggy, especially on my computer. The random ones also tend to have NO SUPPLIES EVER!!! I'm NOT saying it wasn't fun. It was fun! The good parts about the random server are the extra challenge, which yes is VERY difficult to overcome these overpowered opponents, but possible. You can also play the hiding game, where you stealth around and try to kill your overpowered opponents with strategy such as: Using a horde of zombies on them, Making them bleed with a trap, or sneaking up on them and shooting them in the face 50 times with the worst gun in the game. OPTION 2: Playing with friends! I personally found this to be A LOT more fun! There are various mini-games you can play as well. PvE is also a good time! Although I did get bored fairly quickly, it was fun watching my team-mate derp around in a horde of zombies.
Suggestions:
- Create-Your-Own worlds, cars, etc.
- Make the bridge lead to a city area, with MANY more zombies, but better loot.
- Make the arena better in some way
- Make alternate game-modes.
- Add bikes, moter-cycles, and ATV's that go VERY FAST, but you fall off if you hit a zombie and it breaks down faster (A LOT of damage when hitting a zombie).
Overall:
This game made me want to cry when I first played it. I wish I could feel the same feeling of when I first played it! I hope the creator adds some new spicy stuff, including the create-your-own stuff that he is already doing (I think). The game is difficult at first, but you as a player can adapt. This game is VERY GOOD!!!
Personal Rating:           4.5 Stars (Free Game Personal Rating)

This game is amazing once you get into it. Before jumping into a PvP server, play alone and practice your shooting skills. Also, don't be angry when you die in a server, you can get your stuff back in no time. Don't always try to kill everyone you see, you may bite off more then you can chew. Also, if you get a gold account, make your skin color combo 54 118 60, that is the color of the grass. It has saved me a few times from idiots who walk right by you. Keep any of your guns on auto if possible. A few times, I'll forget that I have my gun on semi, and I'll run up on somebody trying to kill them, and one bullet will come out, and GG, you're dead (Unless they have a colt, they you're good). All in all, you have nothing to loose by playing this game, try it out before side with people's opinions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's like DayZ with a better community, less bugs and fun to play.
Unturned can get boring if you're not playing with some friends, but in all seriousness the pros overweigh the cons.

Pros:
- Easy on the computer, as it has mincraft like graphics.
- Weapon and weapon attachment system is strong, and well put together.
- Not many bugs, and is being worked on way more than DayZ
- Community is pretty great
- Free!

Cons:
- Building a fortress/house can become very tedious without any friends to play with.
- Gameplay becomes repetitive after awhile
- Not much content to date
- Needs are realistic in some forms, but at some times, dehydration and hunger needs will be too quick to be realistic in any shape or form.

All that aside, I really look forward to the future of this game and I recommend you play it.

I've never wrote a Steam Review, but I had to take a moment to do so for Unturned :).

This game is just amazing. It's a ton of fun in single player and even more of a blast with friends! The fact that this game has a new patch right around the corner that will allow for community modding, a dedicated server list with VAC and awesome new features is just enough to start playing =P!

The Developer is an amazing person who listens to his community, promotes their content and loves their feedback! Did I mention this game is made by one person (Nelson Sexton: who was 16 at the time it released)! What a boss =P!

Give Unturned a whirl and if you truly enjoy it consider buying the Gold Account Upgrade which is only $5 and helps support the game (nothing pay 2 win)! Either way it's a really awesome game and it's always going to be FREE 2 PLAY!

Have fun and keep it chill!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I started out playing this game punching trees thinking I was in a blocky game of mining, but I wasn't. I got the newsflash when I was gangbanged by 8 harmless looking zombies. I tried to fight back, swinging away with my flashlight, trying to get away but, was ripped limb from limb. Now, after a few long months, I have become a god with metal barricades and doors blocking my lighthouse base.

11/10 would get gangbanged again

Early today,2/16/15, I went to play on my first server on the beta. OPERATION WARSAW I think it was and I began my adventure. After getting an axe and supplies, I mercy killed some zombies. BANG BANG went the gun and old Tyler knew what to do. I peeked over my fence and saw a completely black figure being chased by so zombies. I charged over to go help him and after a minute or so, they were all dead. The man and I exchanged gifts and parted ways. I returned to town to find two completely naked newspawns. Nexdah and hung_well were their names I greated them with a hello and offered beans. Well, I guess they didnt like beans so Nexdah gunned me down as I went for my axe. Well, I cursed them on the almighty world chat and a started to chat to the Admin: connerthegreat1. He was a jovial guy, and was kind enough to spawn a Schofield for me. I was pleased. About 10 minutes later, I saw my recent adversaries, Nexdah and his goon hung_well. I guess they were stil upset abut the beans so they swong and shot at me. I returned fire but was struck in the face. At this point Im dying with laughter so I respawned and walked the dusty road to Ontario to meet the Admin. Opon entering, I was greeted by the best looking base ive ever seen: a crane with a base/bridge thing leading to a skyscaper. I complemented him and I went with a planter full of carrots as a gift. I guess he didnt like them because as soon as i placed them, He shot me with a smile on his face. I fell out of my chair, crying with laughter and left the game.

That was the first and last time I will play on a server.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For being as simplistic as it is, this game is highly addictive. Whether you're choosing to marathon massacre hoards of zombies by the light of the full moon or just slay fields of trees to gather logs for building up your base, this game will keep you on your toes. I was a bit skeptical going into it, I must confess. But I've yet to play a session that I walked away from in less than three or four hours. Highly addictive and super entertaining. On a constructive note, I'm excited see more crafting recipes get added. Once you've built an established base, the options begin to feel very limited on things to fill it.  Still a fun adventure though. :)

Edit: I have really enjoyed watching the game grow and develop as Mr.Sexton continues to update it. Since my original review, many new mechanics have been implemented, including more functionality with items and furniture. So now I have even more incentive to obsessively loot cabinets and hoard candy bars like it's the apocalypse. Because, well, it is. ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Solid survival game. I wasn't very keen when I first tried it and felt lackluster because of my lack of knowledge towards the game. I later picked it back up and played with a friend who is miles more experienced than me and made the game fun for me.

I've only clocked about 40+ hours to this game as I'm writing this and I already love this game so much. Definitely in my top 5 games on my Steam library. That's quite a big statement to make, right? (But definitely not the first. Sorry! :P)

Crafting is very in-depth. Can be very difficult and fustrating at times. Takes awhile to memorize them. I'd still have to refere to the wiki every now and then.  The suvival aspect of this game is very challenge at first, but can be very fustrating later into the game, but surely it's miles easier than when we all first started playing this game. You always need to be wary of your hunger, hydration and sickness.

Building is very fustrating with the terrain around you. The land might look straight but nope, it's just slightly higher. You gotta find the perfect location. I suggest one should always prepare the materials a day before you want to build so you can focus whole heartedly into the build. Ain't nobody wants to stop halfway of their build to go chop more trees, right?

With almost *every* game, it's clearly better played with friends. Adds a lot more fun and speeds up process if you're building. I've never played PvP so I can't give you a good picture of that. Longer hours of playing this game is not recommended. Take 30 mins break every now and then. I once played this game 6 hours straight and felt very heavy and burnt out (was building a huge house).

Summary/conclusion:
Ideal game if you just want to sit down, lay back and kill some zombies for a good 2 hours or 3. Anything exceeding 3 hours might just feel forced and heavy. Building is just a plus to this game. A very big PHAT plus. Nothing is more satisfying than you performing a headshot onto a zombie's head.  I hope you'll like this game as much as I do.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's your classic zombie survival game. At the time, I'd give it a 8/10. But that may change as I play the game more. I'll start out with the Cons, since really that is more important than the Pros.
-Bad driving. You will get use to it if you play it for some time, but when I first drove I had such a hard time.
-Slow. Now, this is and Pro and Con at the same time. It takes a long time for it to go to the next day. I personally like when the days go faster so you can move on. BUT! This is also a good thing. It makes it seem more realistic.
-Servers. This is mostly why I rated this an 8/10. It is a major pain in the ♥♥♥ to create your own server. I'm hoping later on into the game the creators will make it so you can just go onto severs and it will have a button to make your own server. At the moment, you have to go and download a bunch of stuff, and mod some things, and it's just stupid.
-Glitches. This may just be my computer being an ♥♥♥, but while I'm playing my character somtimes starts walking on it's own, and it's gotten me killed SO many times.
Now onto the Pros
-Fun. Now, this is a stupid Pro, but this is a very fun game. I could sit and play it for hours if I could. So if you love survival games, you'll love this one!
-Free to Play. Really, when I first downloaded the game I thought it would be crap, because most free games are. But this one wasn't.
-Atmospheric. I personally find this game beautiful, mostly when it's night. There are small details in the game, such as broken glass, rundown buildings, crashed cars, broken objects, and others.
-Workshop. The Unturned workshop has LOT'S of awesome stuff. Maps, new weapons, clothings, and other stuff. If you get bored of the same three maps in the game, there are always new ones in the workshop.
-Crafting. I enjoy the fact there is crafting in the game. A lot of survival games don't add that.
-Zombies. Well, there are zombies in the game. Freakin zombies man. ZOMBIES. Sorry, I LOVE zombie stuff.
Hope this helped some people decided if they should download this game or not. Go for it.
I'll be updating this once I play the game more, and possibly get the Gold Upgrade. Stay tuned :3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I honestly had no idea what to expect from this game when I first downloaded it. My first impression was some sort of DayZ and Minecraft mash up, and that is sort of what this game is.

First off, don't let the graphics fool you. It is kind of cartoon-ish, but the gameplay is actually better than I thought it would be.
In my opinion, to get the best experience out of this game, you need to play online with some friends. One of my favorite things is having to survive and gather supplies, all the while having to deal with other players who are likely trying to kill you. Its a very fun (and sometimes frustrating) experience.

For being free, and a not fully developed game, this is very good. As far as gameplay issues/bugs go, I haven't really found that many, it runs very well. This is not a game that should be very computer intensive, so most people shouldn't have an issue running it on their computers, and that is another plus to this game.

All in all, if you can't afford some of the zombie survival games out there like DayZ, or if your machine simply cannot run such games, this is a good alternative.

10/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nUnturned is a horror sandbox game. Many people like to compare this to Rust, DayZ, or like Roblox. Although I prefer to call it it's own game due to it's unique style. (Please keep in mind, we all have our opinions.) The game is very balanced, doesn't require much graphics/RAM, and looks very beautiful. You can easily create your own server with some friends and fool around, or make a dedicated one with PVP or PVE. PVE allows you to cancel any Player vs. Player damage, although you still have zombies. The game is currently in devolpment, but is still quite an amazing game, even though it is made by a one man dev team. PVP is something I haven't quite played much due to some issues, but from what I've seen and heard, it is quite balanced with the weaponry and mechanics. I recommend this game happily, and hope the best of luck for this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My grade for this game at this moment is 8/10. Why not 10? Well, the game is free and it is advantage, the whole idea of Unturned is also nice, I appreciate quite number of items, too,  but for this moment it is only possible to play it in single mode or by hamachi with friends. On dedicated servers plenty of cheats are destroying whole game, wallhacks, flyhacks, bugging of items is so common that I doubt that there exists at least one public server where we can play fairly. The next problem which I am gonna  talk about is the size of current map. It is too small to play it by more than 15 players at one moment: too few items, on PvP mode non-stop killing in the same places, and survival game becomes some Counter-Strike or so on.
Summing up, great game with potential, I recommend everyone to play Unturned, but we must wait for update which will eliminate cheats from the server and give us bigger map.

If you can gather the right group of allies and the right weapons this game can be a blast.
Cool system of base building.

Cool crafting mechanics.

Cons:

Overall, I think it is an amazing game but could use a tiny bit of tweaking here and there, but if you are a hardcore sombie survival fan like i am, you will love this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It was a beautiful day to play Unturned. I logged on, went onto my favorite server, and was immediately horrified. My base, the metal masterpiece I'd spent 6 hours building the night before, was gone. When the admin informed me that he wouldn't help in the recreation of my castle, I went into a fit of rage. Luckily, all of my best loot (Assault Rifle, Bandages and plenty of Ammo) was still on my character. I decided to kill each and every person on the server. Which I did. Multiple times. People began to leave. Good riddance. New people would log on, I killed them too. I didn't care if they didn't destroy my base, everyone was a target. Finally, it was just me and the admin left. He built his base in the prison in the center of the map. I killed him and destroyed everything. Then I was promptly banned from the server.

10/10 would rage again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first tried Unturned, it was after I saw it on Steam Greenlight, and that was about 2 months before it was Greenlit, and ever since I've actively played the game. I was a bit skeptical about it at first, but as soon as I hopped on a server with a couple of my friends I fell in love with the game and put countless hours in to it. Unturned, though visually seems like Minecraft or Roblox, is actually a lot more like DayZ or Rust than it is either of those games, and is a great alternative to those games (and in my case, nearly pulled me away from them completely).

The game's graphics though simple actually grow on you (but could use work of course), the game performs well, and overall the game is a blast (especially with friends!). Gold is nice, but I mainly purchased it to support Nelson (the developer). The great thing about Gold though is that it doesn't make the game pay-to-win, I just think gold members deserve a little bit more content.

I highly suggest trying this game, and if you like it as much as I do, I'd definitely purchase Gold whenever you can.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After killing numerous zombies and coming very close to death and defying all the odds, I claimed myself invincible. I finally met my fate after scrambling around the entire pea-sized map trying to finding a bottle of water and died of dehydration.

I respawned and was chased around the pea-sized map by paraplegic zombie who, despite the paralysis of his legs, crawls as fast as a normal zombie. This spitting image of a severely spastic chihuahua dragging it's crotch along the carpet was absolutely relentless. He crawled with the force and speed of a thousand African Americans ramped up on a bottle of 'roids. This ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ chased me around the entire map as I struggled to find my death place.

After finally finding my items spilled along the grassy knoll, he was able to catch me off guard and ultimately chewed my legs off. Following my death, I contimplated my life choices. What had I just gotten myself into? Why had this zombie chased me all this way? I mean, at this point, you might as well give me the ability to shove a improvised firecracker up my squared ♥♥♥♥ and let my blocky intestines fertilize the landscape. But no! I shall not give up yet! I SHALL NOT BE INTIMIDATED!

I reluctantly respawned and was very quickly greeted by, yet again, a reanimated construction worker. But this construction worker was different. Because, you guessed it, he too was a paraplegic. (Just a side note, I consider hiring a paraplegic as a construction worker a very poor business move.) I stared in disbelief as he crawled at Mach 3 speed towards me to slowly nibble my toes to death. I laid my hands into my face as I maniacally laughed, and then cried.


I give this game 10/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If your looking for a review on unturned you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Eat.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I tried this game in early access, and I actually thought some things were better then.

The things that were better in the early access was:
1. The Inventory
2. Zombies not staggering after EVERY hit
3. Weapon rarity, in the newer version you find weapons like everywhere.

And the things better in the current state is:
1. Weapons getting weaker when you use them more
2. The crafting menu that shows what you can craft without having to go to the wiki. This can also be seen as a bad thing.
3. better graphics, that broken tube in the lab that scared the ♥♥♥♥ out of me thinking something would sneak up on me 24/7 and the little things such as the UFO and sliding on ice.
4. Being able to rotate building parts.
5. Different zombies such as the fast crawler and the big, slow, tanky guy.

Here are some things that are really good in both games and should be kept:
1. The skills system. It is simply brilliant that you can focus on building, killing zombies or something else like running faster or sneaking better to avoid zombies.
2. The freedom of building. Just being able to craft so many different building parts (and rotating them in the current version).
3. Different clothes so you can look so swagelicious as possible.
4. The variety of weapons and the freedom of customizing them such as putting a sniper sight on a shotgun <:).

Overall, I prefer the older version more but that's just because I like the simplicity of games. But i will still give this game a 7-8/10 q:^)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nUnturned is a Zombie Apocalypse game, and we already had a lot of those, so what's special with this one? Well, obviosly we have the design, which follow the Minecraft formula, but tweaking that with better shaders, better water and the game itself is much more fun, if you ask me. But i'll say, this game can get a hell of a lot more fun, if you play online, call your friends and try to survive this pretty damn cool Zombie Apocalypse that you are presented with, the mechanics are for the most part well done, just the hit-detection sometimes might get weird, but for a free-to-play early access game, it sures is better than most games of the genre, about that DLC that you can buy, it really doesn't affect the gameplay of non-DLC users, DLC users will only get Cosmetic Suits and two inicial guns that can be turned off, nothing that will eventually unbalance the game, if i could, i would buy the DLC as well, to help this awesome developer, that show how things are done and should be done.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA game where you start off from nothing to something, Minecraft has taught the developers the theme, but alot different. You play to survive against zombies and scavenge through towns to get food, clothes, weapons, water, ect. The weapons are common, food is scarce, and the animals are also a pain sometimes, but it's cool that the game formulates being an actual predator and not screw up your chances for survival. There's another mode known as arena, which is basically Minecraft PvP and building your homes. Crafting is also a bit complicated, I kinda hated bringing the crafting guide up every time I try to build things like foundations, chests, ect. But, overall, I enjoy the fun aspects of it and playing with friends makes it a whole lot better (but starting a server is complicated believe it or not). The game's free, so I hope free speaks your language.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game recontexualizes the horrors of the Rwandan Genocide through it's emphasis of humanitarianist values against the ideals of brainless zombies. The human survivors are fighting against the zombies, metaphorically the horrors of the english and the world around them. The humans can also fight within each other, singifying the fight between Hulu's and Tutsi's, two opposing sides with similar mindsets, to make the land better for their people.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What can I say about this game?

If you love minecraft and and same games to it, you will love Unturned game. I've tried it myself and still making up my mind to go for the gold premium membership ;) The game itself is worth of the 5€, 5$ to support the developer so course here are my cons and pros for the game to make you find helpfull to decide if you want to get it and try it. Don't let my hours of play confuse you because i do love play this game.

Pros :

+Free to play
+Simmilar to Minecraft
+5€, 5$ gold membership (buy once, you keep it with no monthly subscription)
+Driving
+Unlimited resources everytime you start new game (single player)
+Crafting (from items to food and farming)
+Building (collect usefull items for yourself to survive)
+Killing zombies & Hunting animals
+Steam Achievements
+Multi-player & Co-op
+Stats
+Addicted (at least for those who love survival games)
+Co-op with hamachi friends

Cons :

- Everytime you die you loose stats (sometimes half, sometimes all)
- Still needs allot of work on the game servers (doesn't connect to all so you need a bit of luck)
- Game could use a large world map because this map is not big enough

I think that's all i have to say about this game. Try it for yourself and some of you will enjoy but some not. Feel free to comment on the pros and cons that i've write about it.

Time for me to go farm my crops, build a base and use a sledge hammer to kill zombies ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Seems like a Dayz for poor people? Wrong! This is something much better, initialy when you join a server you will have nothing (you are nude), you will search for supplies, weapons, whatever you need. But theres always other players! I myself became frustrated when i keept getting killed by snipers roaming about in police cars with sirens on, i tought they were hackers but i were wrong.

One day i met a black dressed man who asked me if i wanted to join his team and of course i said yes! He then spawned in several machineguns, armors, food and a police car came flying down from the sky and landed on that little annoying microspammer.

I had not known that he was actually an admin and so i joined his team, we sat down in the police car. Turned sirens on and began hunting anything that was alive, zombies, animals, players (Mostly nude players) i spent half an hour sitting in the car shooting with my glorious machine gun not having to worry about running out of ammo because i had 20 clips. We drove over and shot anything in our sight.

Don't fool yourself, there is no competetive multiplayer. Servers exist so that The Owner and his friends can hunt down nude players with machineguns in a police car while players scream: Hackers!" "Help!" "Why you do this?"

Best manslaughter simulator ever 10/10"

This game is amazing!

First of all. Its free, you can play the whole game -a few customization options and other 'stuff'. Also this game is better that DayZ, a £22.99, unfinished game that has been in Alpha state for 2 years, made by several qualified people who get paid a fortune. This masterpeice is made by someone who is younger than be (He is 18(I think)).

There is hundreds of things to find in this game, varing from guns, attachments, ammo, food and tons more. The map (1.3) is huge (16x bigger than the older one).

Lastly, Nelson (Dev) is a talanted young man, and deserves alot more credit than he already gets. This is one of my best PC games I own and look foward to playing more in the future.

10/10 - (P.S, Great for achievements)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review will probably not be seen by many but I will still do it...

The game starts out really slow and hard, but after finding some items and a backpack, it becomes easier and that's when the rewarding stuff starts to come, after a while you will be able to build a base, you will be able to kill zombies with ease and etc. Crafting is good but it needs an in-game crafting recipe book.

Graphics are blocky with bland textures but somehow feel really fitting which is a plus and online is great with friends, it's always fun with other people.
Edit : After upgrading to version 3, the graphics are pretty catchy with the visual overhaul of PEI.

I do agree that the game may get boring when you're alone but this game is not made for SP but MP mainly from my perspective.

You starve to death if you don't eat, you can die because you haven't drank water from alot of time, you became infected... there are alot of stuff to survive from, including zombies so yeah... alot of stuff.

Some items felt useless tho, probably because they are randomly generated and you might end up with alot of useless ones in that particular character.

The driving physics aren't all that good but they work, same goes for shooting mechanics.
Edit: Shooting mechanics were vastly improved in my opinion, driving physics have also been improved, not as much as shooting mechanics tho.
The game is also really good for ''Let's Plays'' so if you decide that you want to record it and share your experience, people will most likely to enjoy it.

Some more pros :
The game is still in Early Access and yet it's really good, that's a plus.
The shaders are realistic and the map is big.

Some cons : There is only 1 map and while it is big, it is not big enough to be only 1 map in the whole game, I am sure that there will be more tho.

Did I mention it's alot less glitchy than Day Z?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is developed by a great team, the team consists of one man neslon sexton,(Dont get mad if I spelled it wrong, also yes I see the irony of his last name being sexton on a valve game medium)  Not only does he make a great game he then gives it away for free, he puts his time and effort into a game that is almost completely free! I have un-dying support and admiralidy for this guy. Anyway, onto the review. This game may look crappy, but trust me, if you crank up the grapics it looks pretty decent.  People complain about body parts being deformed, that may be the case but Ark: Survival Evolved does the same thing.  The games map varies and is very fun to explore, there are secrets hiding everywhere.  The zombies actually have good AI,  AI that puts dayz zombies to shame.  The guns feel powerful and real (despite what they look like) and the fact that ammo for a specific gun is rare it makes you think about each shot (sort of like resident evil).  The servers in this game can be anoying at times, this mostly because the community is garbage, no matter how many times you say your friendly the guy with the compound bow will shoot you, and if you shoot an admin, get off the server emiedietly, or prepare to die.  It is very fun to play with friends on servers though. The game is continually updating, slowly but surely (It is a one man team for gosh sakes). Singleplayer is flawless, no bad community to get in the way and still relatively chalengeing zombies. Sound for a free game especially is not lacking, it is actually not bad. The game for a free game is, ABSOLUTLY AMAZING! And the only gameplay related con is that the map can be glitchy in certain places, like the construction site vault and you may fall through it, which can be very frusterating as you cant get your stuff back when you die. Lets go over the pros and cons of the game.

pros:
-Good map, Varies, and is fun to explore, lots of hidden secrets.
-Graphics are decent.
-Relatively good AI.
-Guns feel real and powerful, rare ammo makes you think about shooting first.
-Fun to play with friends
-Continually updating
-Sound is pretty good.
-FREE.99

cons:
-Guns look like crap and are hard to identify with real life.
-Map can be glitchy
-Community is well, GARBAGE, SHAPE UP!




Remember, players are your worst enemy, be wary of them.  NOW WHAT ARE YOU DOING HERE GO AND PLAY THE DARN GAME!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unturned, yes. What about it? Well, let me tell you, it's one of the best games you will find on Steam. Look around, what do you see, well, I see a game that has an incredible future. Beta 3.0 really brings the game to life with the physics and shading.
[] Starting off with nothing can be quite daunting is some games, but as soon as you find a village you can find a few weapons and clothes.
[] Once you have the basics, why not find a gas can and a car to get you round the map in a minute or two.
[] Next head to confederation bridge to get yourself a weapon and some ammo.
[] Feeling a bit daring, head to the military base and take on the dreaded hulk zombie (you might want a grenade or a lot of ammo) this guy can take some hits. Don't use a melee weapon if you can help it when fighting the hulk zombie, but conserve as much ammo as you can, but don't worry, it's not impossible to find ammo so you can use the odd bit.
[] Find yourself some military clothes (Ninja and ghillie suits look cool, but for bigger carrying spaces use the military clothes and vest).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unturned is a zombie survival game with the graphics of Roblox, crafting ideas of Minecraft and the concept of Dayz.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Singleplayer:
Rate: 8/10
Pros:
- Tutorial that help you learn the controls of the game.
- Easy game to run and small download.
- Getting started is very easy.
- Balanced PVE.
- Fun game
Cons:
- 1 person can loot the entire map in about 2 hours.
- Very boring to play alone after you get set-up.
- Crafting is time consuming and hard to learn.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Multiplayer:
Rate: 2/10
Pros:
- Easy to set-up servers with Hamachi
- Sync to multiplayer servers.
Cons:
- Very very hard to find a working server from a server list.
- Hackers.  Every server has some. (main reason why multiplayer sucks)
- Sync to multiplayer servers.
- Kicked for suspected teleportation a lot. (this happens on the laggy servers)
- Map is very very very very very small for a server.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Overall this game has a very good start.  It has the right ideas and gets updates almost everyday.  Gold is kind of a donation at the moment.(I hope they do more with that)  This game needs a bigger map and needs a solution to all the multiplayer problems.  Playing with friends is very fun though.(hours of gameplay)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Definitely one of the top game projects ever done by a single person.

This game is pretty much a minecraft zombie survival world and it shines as a multiplayer experience of course. The surprise is how well polished it is. With many working features, fun combat, fun items, fun crafting/building, and all for free? I wasn't really a voxel sandbox fan when I started but this game helped me see the appeal.

The only thing it could really use is workshop support. That would solve any lack of content/maps/modes problems. But it's fun chasing down deers and pigs with an axe or slaughtering an entire horde of zombies.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OK long time has passed since my last review on this game so why not write a new one? Here we go then...
Unturned is zombie survival, base building and looting game. This game has everything what good game needs. Base building is very good and wth the newest update 3.13.6.0 it's even better! Zombies are like normal zombies, killing ♥♥♥♥, guarding great loots. Inventory system is very cool in my opinion, to be honest all games should have grid-type inventory (this inventory system reminds me good old Rezident Evil 4 times). The weapons have great recoil and damage values. And it has ♥♥♥♥ing workshop and map editor. That means u will never play same game all over again, u can make mod it however u want! Oh and it has great level/skills system. And the best thing that it's free.... To be honest this is the best non-MMO/RPG free game on steam.The only bad thing is that you kinda get bored of this game pretty quickly. For me, mainly becouse of it's minecraft-like graphics. Maybe it's only for me but whatever...  THIS IS GREAT FREE GAME AND I HIGHLY RECOMMENT IT.
PS: I recomment you supporting Nelson (game creator) by buying Gold edition. It's like 5 euros and basicly gives u gold suit (yes it has marketing/item system), few more characters and access to double loot/xp servers. I bougth it becouse I wanted to support Nelson. And yes, it was made by one ♥♥♥♥ing guy..HE MADE A BETTER GAME THEN WHOLE GAME COMPANIES TRY TO MAKE AND FAILS (I AM LOOKING AT YOU CALL OF ♥♥♥♥ AND ASSASINS CREED UNITY). AND HE WAS 15 YEARS OLD BY THE TIME HE MADE THIS... It's just mind blowing then u better think about it..

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Before you rate my review - please read it*    *This review was made after update 2.1.7*

I can't tell if I love or hate this game. This game is fun for a short(!) time. I really had a good time with my friends.

The reason why this game is only fun for a short time is because you can get the good stuff in this game really really fast.
If you get to the airport and/or the military-base you almost have all the good stuff.
And the zombies aren't a threat. The only real threat is hunger(You can grow plants or hunt). If you have a base, players aren't a threat.

This is just my opinion, but it doesnt really have any replay value for me(But I will check it out again when there is a new update)
I've played Rust and DayZ. I like survival games. But I dont find this one challenging. It also doesn't have alot of items/content.

I still had a good time playing Unturned"

I'm still giving this game a good rating
